message: More specifically: how is the current environment? Is there money there? How do the mentoring/incubation programs stack up to Silicon Valley? Etc.
Pack your bags to Palo Alto, that is where it is at. or SF.
There is a new incubator for Clean Technologies being formed in Dallas. CleanTechOpen
What's the word on Tech Wildcatters or Star Tech? We can't all visit beautiful Cali.
leaving dallas to join a startup in SF was one of the best decisions i made
How did you start your move? Did you have a company in mind before you left?

hard to answer that question, my instinct is to say you should be a programmer type if you hope to get into a startup very early on, but there's an obvious need for marketing/bd types at a most startups
a friend from school joined joined me a few weeks later at the same startup
yeah, I had a job offer from a startup, packed a bag and left
What type of skills are most valued in the valley? Do you have to be a hardcore programmer, or do interdisciplinary ppl work as well?
If you are lookung for a good source of information regarding technology incubator/accelerator look at the the Foundry Group and Tech Stars in Boulder, CO. Brad Feld and Cohorts do a great job.
@benwmax Every major city in Texas has quite a bit going for it, but Austin seems to be where the majority of the tech startup scene is.
Austin is like the perfect storm. Tech, design, and money. It is also condensed, where DFW could sit beside the definition of "sprawl"
So what would it take to bring the startup "vibe" to Dallas?
We like the guys at Dallas based Appvita & Magnt. Dave Onkels (http://daveonkels.com/) is a good guy and knows his way around the startup community there.

I used to live in Dallas for 5 years and had a startup, but am now am in chicago.  Chicago is definitely more of a vibrant startup community than Dallas, but it's still no where near the valley or even NYC.  Both cities have a lot of work to do.  I know there are a few iOS app dev firms in Chicago, including Red Laser I believe.  But @jeffreyryanwho is correct that Dave Onkels is a good guy and releasing some cool stuff (predecessor to about.me)
